Technical Assistance Report
 
 
 
Project Number: 51065-001 
Regional Transaction Technical Assistance Facility 
June 2017 
 
Strengthening Domestic Transport Connectivity in 
the Pacific
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB’s Public Communications 
Policy 2011. 
 
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

CONTENTS 
Page 
 
TRANSACTION TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FACILITY AT A GLANCE 
 
I.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FACILITY  1 
A.  Justification  1 
B.  Outputs and Activities  3 
C.  Cost and Financing  4 
D.  Implementation Arrangements  4 
E.  Governance  5 
II.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  5 
 
APPENDIXES  
1.  Cost Estimates and Financing Plan  6 
2.  Projects under Technical Assistance Facility  7 
3.  List of Linked Documents  8

I.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FACILITY 
A.  Justification 
1.  The proposed transaction TA facility will provide project preparation and policy advice 
support to a series of ensuing projects, comprising: (i) Solomon Islands Guadalcanal Road 
Rehabilitation Project, (ii) Tonga Fanga’uta Lagoon Crossing Project, and (iii) an investment 
proposal in Vanuatu. All ensuing projects will improve domestic transport connectivity in the 
countries being covered. The proposed transaction TA will also provide advisory support to the 
Government of Vanuatu to formulate a national transport sector investment policy and plan. 
 
2.  The Pacific island countries of Solomon Islands, Tonga, and Vanuatu (target countries) 
share similar characteristics. By regional standards, they are mid-range in terms of size and 
population. They are significantly smaller in size and population than the larger Pacific countries 
such as Papua New Guinea, Timor Leste, and Fiji, although larger than the micro states of Tuvalu 
and Nauru. Tonga’s population is about 100,000, Solomon Islands’ population is about 600,000, 
and Vanuatu’s population is about 250,000. The target countries are geographically isolated and 
far from main commercial centers. Tonga is located about 2,000 km from New Zealand and 3,000 
km from Australia, while Solomon Islands and Vanuatu are located about 2,000 km from both 
Australia and New Zealand.  
 
3.  Domestic transport connectivity in the target countries mostly depends upon roads and 
interisland shipping. These modes of transport are critical to provide essential services, improve 
trade and tourism, and access to domestic and international markets.  Road transport is an 
important subsector, especially on larger islands where the road network provides access to key 
economic  links  such  as  tourism  and  agriculture.  Roads  also  provide  access  to  essential 
government services including health and education. They also serve as an important intermodal 
link, providing access to ports and airports, thereby facilitating the movement of people and goods 
for inter and intra-island travel. 
 
4.  To achieve the full intended service life and level of service of transport infrastructure 
assets,  proactive  routine  and  periodic  road  needs  to  be  prioritized  through  sound  asset 
management systems, especially where natural disasters and/or high intensity rainfall can quickly 
exacerbate the poor condition of the road. Road conditions can also be undermined by the 
movement  of  overloaded  vehicles  from  forestry,  agriculture,  construction,  and  other  heavy 
industries. The main constraints to the delivery of efficient transport infrastructure and services 
are hampered by characteristics shared by the target countries, including (i) insufficient capacity 
of institutions responsible for infrastructure delivery to implement sustainable routine and periodic 
maintenance programs, (ii) inadequate fiscal budgets to allocate required financial resources for 
recurrent maintenance and rehabilitation,  (iii) vulnerability to natural disasters and anticipated 
climate change, and (iv) limited transport sector policy and legislation.  
 
5.  Due to these systemic issues, a large proportion of the road networks in the three target 
countries is poor as they have exceeded their lifecycle and have been neglected. Poor road 
conditions increase the time for road users to travel and the cost to operate their vehicles. Poor 
road conditions also lead to an increase in road crashes, which results in significant economic 
losses.  Insufficient  road  safety  furniture,  poor  driving  behavior,  and  a  lack  of  road  safety 
awareness of vehicle occupants, pedestrians, and other road users are further factors that 
constrain the safe movement of passengers and goods in the target countries.

2 
6.  The proposed transaction TA facility will provide the governments of Solomon Islands, and 
Vanuatu  preparatory  support  for  projects  that  will  improve  domestic  connectivity  through 
investments targeted at rehabilitating or upgrading existing infrastructure assets. The proposed 
transaction TA facility will provide preparatory support for a new capital project in Tonga to 
improve the road network redundancy.   
 
7.  Solomon Islands. The Ministry of Infrastructure Development (MID) manages national 
land and non-commercial maritime transport infrastructure in Solomon Islands. Land transport is 
the country’s second dominant mode of transport, after maritime, and the road network is 1,875 
km long, of which only 6% is sealed and the rest unsealed. Investments in transport infrastructure 
are prioritized through the 30 year National Transport Plan (NTP), from which a Medium-term 
Transport Action Plan (MTTAP) is formulated and prioritizes investment needs over 2017-2021. 
The MTTAP estimates financing required for some 48 priority projects in the land and maritime 
subsectors estimated at SI$775 million or $104 million equivalent.  From these priorities, there is 
a financing gap of SI$185 million or about $24 million equivalent.  The Government of Solomon 
Islands has requested ADB’s support to prepare feasibility studies to upgrade 12 km and 
rehabilitate 68 km of roads on Guadalcanal, which provides essential access to the national 
capital, Honiara. The roads selected are priorities under the MTTAP and part of the financing gap. 
 
8.   Vanuatu.  The Ministry of Infrastructure and Public Utilities (MIPU) is responsible for the 
management of national transport infrastructure which includes 22 public ports and jetties, and 
the 2,223 km long public road network. National transport infrastructure has deteriorated due to 
a lack of maintenance. In 2017, the budget allocated for transport infrastructure maintenance is 
Vatu 1,200 million or about $11 million equivalent, which is about half of the project annual 
maintenance needs estimated at Vatu 2,200 million or $20 million equivalent. The deteriorated 
condition of infrastructure has been further exacerbated by damage caused by Tropical Cyclone 
Pam, which struck Vanuatu in May 2015. The government in 2015 endorsed the Vanuatu 
Infrastructure Strategic Investment Plan (VISIP) which covers all infrastructure sectors. The VISIP 
identifies the need for an integrated transport sector plan to articulate national transport sector 
policy and prioritize infrastructure emergency works, maintenance, rehabilitation, upgrading, and 
new development.  
 
9.   The Government of Vanuatu has requested ADB to support the formulation of a national 
transport sector plan, focusing on (i) transport infrastructure planning and asset management, (ii) 
sources and allocation of recurrent maintenance financing, (iii) institutional capacity of transport 
line agencies, and (iv) a roadmap for policy, regulatory, and institutional reforms on relevant areas 
such as road safety, weight limits, and climate change adaptation. In addition, the VISIP has 
identified South Santo Road as a priority project, for which feasibility studies are needed and 
could be supported under the proposed transaction TA facility. 
 
10.  Tonga. The capital, Nuku’alofa, situated on the main island Tongatapu, is located on a 
low-lying area in a region that is vulnerable to natural disasters, including floods and tsunamis. 
The Taufa’ahau corridor is the main transport link into and out of Nuku’alofa during peak hour 
travel times. The Government of Tonga has requested ADB’s support to evaluate and prepare 
feasibility studies for a new transport link featuring a bridge or crossing from Nuku’alofa to 
southern Tongatapu, across Fanga’uta lagoon. The new link would span about 500 meters across 
the shortest route over the lagoon, and would provide (i) shorter journeys to the capital for people 
living in central and eastern parts of Tongatapu, resulting in savings for travel time and vehicle 
operating costs, and (ii) a high capacity link out of Nuku’alofa that could be used as an evacuation 
route to higher areas in the event of a tsunami. In evaluating such a proposal, it should be 
compared against other viable alternatives, such as providing an evacuation route through the

3 
existing Taufa’ahau corridor with effective traffic and evacuation management and/or upgrading 
its existing capacity.  
 
11.  The proposed transaction TA facility is listed in the current Regional Operations Business 
Plan (ROBP).1 The proposed transaction TA facility will support priorities in the Pacific Approach2 
by preparing new transport infrastructure investments that (i) are resilient to anticipated climate 
change and natural disaster impacts, and (ii) will improve domestic and regional connectivity, 
thereby enhancing access to business opportunities and social services. The TA is categorized 
as complex, as the ensuing project for Tonga is anticipated to be environment category A.    
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
12.  The major outputs and activities are summarized in Table 1.  
 
Table 1: Summary of Major Outputs and Activities 
Major Outputs  Delivery Dates  Key Activities with Milestones 
1. Vanuatu National  30 September  1.1  Provide  an  overarching  vision  and  policy  for 
Transport Sector  2018  transport  infrastructure  in  Vanuatu,  based  on  a 
Investment Policy and  review of existing relevant national policies, plans, 
Plan  and transport sector assessment in Vanuatu. (Q3 
2017)

and Plan. (Q3 2018)

Source: Asian Development Bank estimates. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The TA facility is estimated to cost $2,000,000, all of which will be provided by ADB on a 
grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-6). The key expenditure items 
are listed in Appendix 1. 
 
14.  The governments of Solomon Islands, Tonga, and Vanuatu will provide counterpart 
support  in  the  form  of  counterpart  staff,  office  accommodation,  office  supplies,  domestic 
transportation, and other in-kind contributions. The governments were informed that approval of 
the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  ADB will be the executing agency for the TA, with the Pacific Department as the focal point 
for  the  TA.  The  implementing  agencies  in  the  participating  countries  will  be  Ministry  of 
Infrastructure, Land Transport Department (MOI-LTD) in Tonga, MID in Solomon Islands and 
MIPU in Vanuatu.  
 
Table 2: Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects   Arrangements 
Indicative implementation period  June 2017–June 2019 
Executing agency  Asian Development Bank 
Implementing agencies  Ministry of Infrastructure, Land Transport Department, Tonga 
Ministry of Infrastructure Development, Solomon Islands 
Ministry of Infrastructure and Public Utilities, Vanuatu 
Consultants  To be selected and engaged by ADB 
  Individual Consultant  11 person-months  $300,000 
Selection 
  Quality and Cost  52 person-months  $1,500,000 
Based Selection 
(90:10)

5 
Aspects   Arrangements 
Advance contracting  Advance contracting will be administered for the Transport Policy and 
Planning Specialist through individual consultant selection, and for the 
Project Preparation Firm through quality and cost based selection. 
Disbursement  The TA resources will be disbursed following ADB's Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
Asset turnover or disposal  Fixed assets will be handed over to the respective government in each 
arrangement upon TA completion  country upon TA completion. 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
16.  Consulting services. The TA will require 2 consulting assignments. The first assignment 
to develop a National Transport Sector Strategy and Plan for Vanuatu will require an individual 
Transport Policy and Planning Specialist and individual Maritime Specialist consisting of 11 
international  person-months  (pm).  The  individual  will  be  selected  by  ADB  using  Individual 
Consultant Selection, and will use an input-based contract with liquidation of advance. The 
second assignment to primarily identify and prepare investment proposals in the three target 
countries will require a consulting firm requiring as a minimum the following international expertise: 
Team  Leader/Transport  Planner/Economist  (12  person-months),  Financial  Analyst/Financial 
Management Specialist (4 person-months), Social Safeguards Specialist (8 person-months), 
Environment Specialist (8 person-months), Climate and Disaster Risk Specialist (3 person-
months),  Roads  Engineer  (6  person-months),  Roads  Safety  Engineer  (2  person-months), 
Structural Engineer (6 person-months), Procurement Specialist (3 person-months), and Social 
and Poverty Specialist (4 person-months). The consultant firm will be selected by ADB using 
quality and cost-based selection (90:10), and will use an output-based, lump sum contract with 
provision of fixed out-of-pocket expenditures. Selection of consultants will commence in June 
2017, with mobilization of individual consultant targeted by July 2017 and mobilization of the firm 
targeted by September 2017. Inputs are indicative and may be realigned to the TA’s requirements. 
The consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time).3 
 
E.  Governance  
 
17.  Since ADB is the executing agency, the financial management, procurement, and integrity 
risks during TA implementation are assessed to be low. However, thorough risk assessments for 
financial management, procurement, and integrity for ensuing investment projects implemented 
in any of the target countries will be conducted under the TA. 
 
II.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $2,000,000 on a grant basis to 
the Solomon Islands, Tonga, and Vanuatu, for Strengthening Domestic Transport Connectivity in 
the Pacific, and hereby reports this action to the board. 
 
 
Takehiko Nakao 
President 
June 2017 
                                                
3  Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).
